Row.Text: Internal Trade Routes produce +33% more [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. Each [ICON_PUPPET] puppet connected via Internal Trade Route yields +4 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and an additional +5 [ICON_PEACE] Faith if following a different religion than your Capital.

10% of [ICON_FOOD] Food is carried over after a new [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People generation in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built next to a River or Lake.

Like the Garden that it replaces, the unique Ottoman Hammam increases the speed at which [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People are generated. In addition, however, it decreases the amount of [ICON_FOOD] Food a city needs to increase in size by 10% and provides a small boost in [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness. Hammams can be constructed only in cities next to a river or lake.

Cleanliness was extremely important in Ottoman culture. Before modern plumbing, the Ottomans constructed communal steam baths ("hammams") throughout their major cities. In early times many of these were attached to mosques - ritual cleanliness played an important part in the Ottoman religious beliefs - in later periods they evolved into separate buildings and eventually, into enormous complexes of buildings.
Mounted Unit specialized in defeating enemy Gunpowder Units. May only be built by the Ottomans. This Unit is faster and can see further than the Lancer, which it replaces.

The Sipahi is the Ottoman unique unit, replacing the Lancer. The Sipahi is much faster and can see one hex farther than the Lancer, although it shares the Lancer's weaknesses on defense. The Sipahi can pillage enemy improvements at no additional cost and gains a bonus against Gunpowder Units. It upgrades into the Cavalry.
